introduction.p: Many shapes, even ones as simple as circles, cannot be represented as an equation where y is a function of x. Consider, for example, the path a moon follows as it orbits around a planet, which simultaneously rotates around a sun. In some cases, equations using polar coordinates (see ) provide a way to represent such a path. In others, we need a more versatile approach that allows us to represent both the x and y coordinates in terms of a third variable, or parameter.

assemblage.p: A system of parametric equations is a pair of functions x(t) and y(t) in which the x and y coordinates are the output, represented in terms of a third input parameter, t.

statement.p: Moving at a constant speed, an object moves at a steady rate along a straight path from coordinates (-5,3) to the coordinates (3,-1) in 4 seconds, where the coordinates are measured in meters. Find parametric equations for the position of the object.

solution.p:
The x coordinate of the object starts at -5 meters, and goes to +3 meters, this means the x direction has changed by 8 meters in 4 seconds, giving us a rate of 2 meters per second. We can now write the x coordinate as a linear function with respect to time, t:
x(t) = -5 + 2t.
Similarly, the y value starts at 3 and goes to -1, giving a change in y value of 4 meters, meaning the y values have decreased by 4 meters in 4 seconds, for a rate of -1 meter per second, giving equation y(t)=3-t.
Using these equations, we can build a table of t, x, and y values. Because of the context, we limited ourselves to non-negative t values for this example, but in general you can use any values.

table.caption: Table of values for parametric equations x(t)=-5+2t and y(t)=3-t

solution.p: From this table, we could create three possible graphs: a graph of x vs. t, which would show the horizontal position over time, a graph of y vs. t, which would show the vertical position over time, or a graph of y vs. x, showing the position of the object in the plane.

subsection.title: Parameterizing the Unit Circle
subsection.p:
In , we explored how the unit circle can be described as the collection of all (x,y)-coordinates that satisfy the equation
x^2 + y^2 = 1.
It is not possible to rewrite this in a form y=f(x). The best we can do is express just the top half of the circle in the form y=f(x), or just the bottom half of the circle, as depicted in .

image.description: top and bottom half unit circle formulae

subsection.p: If we could write down an expression for the unit circle in a form y=f(x), it would be convenient for graphing. We could build a table of (x,y)-coordinates by plugging various x values into the function f(x) and finding corresponding y values, then draw a graph based on the table of values.

However, above shows how one can still draw a graph by building a table of (x,y)-coordinate values using parametric equations (by plugging in various values for t into each equation for the x- and y-coordinates). Throughout this section, we'll see many examples of shapes for which y is not a function of x, but we can describe their graphs using parametric equations.

solution.p: These equations should look familiar. Back when we first learned about sine and cosine we found that the coordinates of a point on the unit circle at an angle of \theta will be x=\cos\theta, y=\sin\theta. The equations above are in the same form with t used in place of \theta.

This suggests that for each value of t, these parametric equations give a point on the unit circle at the angle corresponding to t. At t=0, the graph would be at x=\cos(0), y=\sin(0), the point (1,0). Indeed, these equations describe the equation of the unit circle, drawn counterclockwise.

image.description: first quadrant circle with right triangle and polar coordinates

solution.p: The difference with these equations is the graph would start at x=\sin(0), y=\cos(0), the point (0,1). As t increases from 0, the x value will increase, indicating these equations would draw the graph in a clockwise direction.

subsection.title: Parameterizing Other Circles
subsection.p: In , we reviewed the rules for how changes to formulae (of the form y=f(x)) are related to transformations of graphs of functions. With parametric equations, although we may not be able to represent a curve in a form y=f(x), we'll find that it is very intuitive to adjust our parametric equations for standard transformations of functions.

subsubsection.title: Circle of Radius r Centered at the Origin
subsubsection.p: Let's start by considering a simultaneous vertical and horizontal stretch by a factor of r, which when applied to the unit circle, actually results in a circle of radius r centered at the origin (see ).

image.description: unit circle stretched by factor of r

subsubsection.p: This was determined because the functions cosine and sine give the x- and y-coordinates, respectively, of points on the unit circle. Although we're slightly more used to thinking about how \cos\theta and \sin\theta are related to points on the unit circle, it is a standard practice to use the variable t in parametric equations, so as t increases, we think of the angle at the origin measured from the positive x-axis increasing (and therefore, the circle is drawn counterclockwise as t increases in the parametric equations.

sidebyside.p: shows how the x- and y-coordinates of a point on the circle of radius r centered at the origin relate to the angle measured from the positive x-axis. We label this angle t right away, since it will be used in a set of parametric equations.

image.description: first quadrant circle radius r with right triangle and polar coordinates

subsubsection.p:
The coordinates expressed in terms of r and t come from the following relationships relating to the right triangle drawn in :
\text{cosine} = \frac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}} \;\;\;\;\;\;\;\; \text{sine} = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}}
For example, the first relationship tells us that \cos(t)=\frac{x}{r}, so multiplying both sides by r gives x=r\cos(t).
Let's add one more type of transformation before we formalize this result.

subsubsection.title: Circles Not Centered at the Origin
subsubsection.p: A circle not centered at the origin can be obtained by starting with a circle centered at the origin (of the same radius) and shifting it horizontally some number of unts, then vertically some number of units. See for a detailed example of obtaining a circle not centered at the origin as a result of these types of shifts.

First, the x-coordinate of the center of the circle is now h instead of 0, which means that we need to shift the circle horizontally by h units, or equivalently, we need to add h units to the x-coordinate of each point on the circle centered at the origin. With parametric equations, the x-coordinates have their very own equation, so it is actually very convenient to isolate and adjust exactly what we need with the x-coordinates to build X(t):
X(t) = x(t) + h = r \cos(t) + h.

Similarly, we may obtain a formula for the y-coordinates of the circle centered at (h,k) by realizing they are related to the y(t), the y-coordinates of the circle centered at the origin, but shifted by k units:
Y(t) = y(t) + k = r \sin(t) + k.
In summary, we have a nice general way of building parametric equations to describe any circle in the plane:

subsection.title: Parameterizing Ellipses
subsection.p: Recall from that we can describe an ellipse as being a circle which is stretched both horizontally and vertically, but not by the same stretch factor. Our goal in this section is to come up with a set of parametric equations that can describe a general ellipse.

Above, we build parametric equations for a circle of radius r by multiplying both the x- and y-coordinate functions by a factor of r, thus stretching the circle uniformly by a factor of r both horizontally and vertically.

First, let's consider what happens when we stretch the unit circle horizontally by a factor of 5. In doing just this, we wish to adjust the x-coordinates of points on the graph while leaving the y-coordinates unchanged. Again, with parametric equations, the x- and y-coordinates are isolated into separate equations, so it is convenient to stretch out only the x-coordinates by a factor of 5:
X(t) = 5 \cdot x(t) = 5 \cos(t).
Similarly, we can define Y(t) to represent a vertical stretch by a factor of 3, adjusting only the y-coordinates:
Y(t) = 3 \cdot y(t) = 3 \sin(t).
The following set of parametric equations is therefore the result of stretching the unit circle horizontally by a factor of 5 and vertically by a factor of 3, giving a set of parametric equations to describe the ellipse as desired: \begin{align*} X(t) \amp= 5 \cos(t) \\ Y(t) \amp= 3 \sin(t) \end{align*}
